text: diabetic neuropathy is a result of damage to the nerves nerves help us to feel sensations and also play an important part in the function of our organs diabetic neuropathy is a
long-term complication that can develop over years or decades with good blood glucose control neuropathy can be significantly delayed or avoided the first instances of nerve damage are
likely to be noticed as reduced feeling in the body's extremities such as the hands and feet later symptoms may include tingling numbness pain or burning feeling in the hands or feet if
nerve damage affects the organs symptoms could include delayed stomach emptying or digestive problems faintness or dizziness or sexual difficulties the symptoms of early in Europe they can be
detected by having your feet checked at least once a year a doctor or specialist will perform simple checks on your feet to test for the sensitivity of your feeling and your blood circulation the
primary way to treat nerve damage is to put extra emphasis on maintaining good blood glucose control if neuropathy is causing pain or discomfort painkillers may be prescribed to ease the symptoms
